title: Informed Sampling Strategies for Efficient and Low-Dose Scanning (Transmission) Electron Microscopy
content: Low-dose scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) is typically used when imaging a specimen consisting of beam sensitive materials. Typical methods for minimizing electron dose include, for example, reducing the dwell time and lowering the beam current [1]. With the use of a bayesian dictionary learning algorithm based on Beta Process Factor Analysis (BPFA), dose can be further reduced by sampling a portion of the available pixels [2]. This will subject less of the specimen to degradation through the electron beam, while still being able to view a full image of the sample with live reconstruction [3].
